awd_titl_txt: Biomimetic and Rubisco-Inspired CO2 Capture from Air
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Rainer Glaser of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Missouri, Columbia is developing carbon dioxide capture and release (CCR) systems for the reversible carbon dioxide capture from air. The design of this biomimetic CCR systems is informed by the understanding of the binding of carbon dioxide in the active site of the enzyme rubisco. A simple device for carbon dioxide enrichment in agricultural greenhouses is developed to demonstrate the CCR concept in a field test. Future use is envisioned for large-scale, distributed carbon dioxide removal from air and its subsequent permanent capture and storage. The project provides cross-disciplinary training (mechanistic, structural and computational chemistry; protein synthesis, and biomaterials). Additional broader impacts are achieved through the development of the "Chemistry is in the News" project in science communication and the scientific writing curriculum to instruct students about the scientific process, scientific writing, scientific peer review, and professional ethics.  

Detailed thermodynamic analyses performed for the carbon dioxide capture reaction with a small molecule model demonstrates the promise of rubisco-inspired, small peptide biomimetics as CCR systems with low energy requirements for carbon dioxide release. The realization of energy-efficient CCR systems requires the development of carbon dioxide capture reactions with negative reaction entropies of substantial magnitude. It is the goal of this research to identify small peptides with capture thermochemistry most suitable for effective capture and energy-efficient release. For this purpose, libraries of free and immobilized tetrapeptides are synthesized. Specific experiments include (a) silica particle synthesis and surface functionalization,(b) peptide immobilization on various supports,(c) characterization by spectroscopy and by peptide crystallography,(d) quantitative measurements of carbon dioxide sorption/desorption,and (e) the fabrication of a simple device for carbon dioxide enrichment. The experimental effort is accompanied by theoretical studies of the library of tetrapeptides to determine the thermochemistry and the kinetics of the carbon dioxide addition to the magnesium complexed tetrapeptides, to assess alternatives to magnesium.

por.por_cntn:
In spite of all political efforts to attempt to curtail CO2 emissions, atmospheric CO2 concentrations continue to rise, and the rise has been accelerating (https://keelingcurve.ucsd.edu/). As this trend continues, the need for direct CO2 capture from air will increase. Once direct CO2 capture from air will find its place as a high-priority mediation technology, more and more attention will be paid (a) to the energy consumption of the CCR system, (b) to the scalability of the CCR system, and (c) to the storage of captured CO2.

We have argued for over a decade that rubisco-mimetic CCR systems are excellent performers with regard to the energy consumption of the CCR system. We argued many years ago [1] that CCR systems need to have capture reactions with low exergonicity to ensure low-energy reversibility. We suggested that a rubisco-mimetic model would work perfectly, and we described the function of the active site to arrive at a clear conceptual framework (Figure 1).

We have studied the structures, properties, and active site carbamylation reaction of rubisco enzyme with ONIOM methods. We have studied the carbamylation of all kinds of KDDE-based oligopeptides, of natural and unnatural (fluorinated) lysines, and of simple amines in aqueous solution as a function of pH.

Ten years on, we have confirmed those expectations experimentally and also with higher level theoretical studies [2,3]. A major step along the way was the insight that the lysine's ammonium ion pKa depression by the rubisco environment can be achieved by appropriate fluorination of lysine in the oligopeptide. These KDDE-based systems work so well that we literally can capture CO2 at night (when temperatures decrease) and release CO2 during daytime (when temperatures go up). We have been working with KDDE-type CCR materials in the 50 - 150 mg range which were made by solid-state peptide synthesis. The next challenge is the large-scale synthesis of KDDE-type CCR materials by chemical synthesis for use in pilot plants.

The studies have been pursued by three former graduate students, Dr. Joseph Schell (Ph.D. .20), Dr. Kaidi Yang (Ph.D. '22), and Dr. Brian Jameson (Ph.D. '23). Several undergraduate students have been involved at various times, and Kari Knobbe (B.S. '21) contributed just like a graduate student.

The largest impact of our work on teaching and educational experiences (and also on the development of human resources) comes from our decade-long efforts to teach on Scientific Writing and Authoring, Science Communication, and Science Ethics in the summer programs at various universities in China including most prominently the University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (UCAS), Beijing, Northwest University (NWU), Xi'an, and Northwest Polytechnical University (NPU), Xi'an. While these in-person efforts were curtailed since 2020, the PI and his team have made every effort to develop those lines of a pedagogy research in collaboration with Dr. Guo of UCAS. We presented to communities of interest at three important national and international conferences and these are the 2020 ACS Fall National Meeting, San Francisco, CA, the 2021 ACS Fall National Meeting, Atlanta, GA, and Pacifichem 2021, Honolulu, HI.

[1] Biomimetic Approaches to Reversible CO2 Capture From Air. N-Methylcarbaminic Acid Formation in Rubisco-Inspired Models. Rainer Glaser, Paula O. Castello-Blindt, and Jian Yin. Chapter 17 in New and Future Developments in Catalysis. Activation of Carbon Dioxide, Steven L. Suib (Ed.), 1st ed., Elsevier Publishers: Aug. 2013, pp. 501-534. DOI: 10.1016/B978-0-444-53882-6.00018-8. PDF. SI.

[2] NMR Study of CO2 Capture by Butylamine and Oligopeptide KDDE in Aqueous Solution. Capture Efficiency and Gibbs Free Energy of the Capture Reaction as a Function of pH. Kaidi Yang, Joseph Schell, Fabio Gallazzi, Wei Wycoff, and Rainer Glaser. ChemPhysChem 2023, 24, e202300053 (1 of 14). DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/cphc.202300053. PDF. SI1 (BuNH2), SI2 (KDDE), and SI3 (oligo f3). This article also appears in: Hot Topic: Carbon Dioxide

[3] NMR Study of CO2 Capture by Fluoroalkylamines: Ammonium Ion pKa Depression via Fluorine Modification and Thermochemistry of Carbamylation. Brian Jameson, Kari Knobbe, and Rainer Glaser. J. Org. Chem. 2023, 88, 11434-11544. DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.3c00701. PDF. SI.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2024
Modified by: Rainer E Glaser
